commentThread.commentText: Im 18 and I got a menisectomy right after I turned 17 and it was a terrible decision. After a year it started to hurt again after no physical strain and now I'm back at square one with 20% less of my right lateral meniscus. Moral of the story is to get opinions from multiple doctors, and avoid letting them cut pieces out of you if possible.
Joe 'minor meniscus tear' Rogan
Define a dickhead?
Bash a profession cause you don't understand

Doctors have that ageist mentality because there are certain physiological changes that happen as you get older which makes some diseases more likely than others so that is why medicine seems to be ageist, because some diseases actually happened to b e ageist and using that experience a nd common trends (albeit doesn't help in individual cases such as this man) do work for the majority and save on money for tests etc (medical professionals are also businessmen with a budget) However I do agree t hat age is improving and 50 is young because life expectancy is massively improving, so the mentality for doing more drastic approaches should have a higher cut off, however this will be a developmental change over time over generations it can't happen so quickly
I like how at 5:50 he says "once your body deteriorates it's hard to bring it back" but right before then he criticizes doctors who discourage older people from getting work done

replies.commentText: Sandeep Kumar he knows that it's hard , but that doesn't mean we shouldn't try . It wasn't contradictory at all

commentThread.commentText: The medical profession is a scam. Think about it. Every year of my life, and I'm almost 50, the taxpayers of the USA have spent over $1 billion dollars to research a cure for cancer. And that fails to include all the money raised by these so-called cancer charities as well as various State government taxpayer fleecing operations. So fast forward to when I was 27 and the doctors told me I had cancer. Yes, at 27. Uncommon but not unheard of. Just ask Dirk Benedict. So they prescribed me a certain toxic synthetic drug, which I never got filled, and I went to two other specialists who gave me the same exact course of action including that same prescription which I never got filled. To be clear, they prescribed me with let's just call it drug C. I was supposed to take it until the prescription ran out. If I was still having problems, I would be prescribed drug B and rinse and repeat. If I was still having problems I was supposed to be prescribed drug A and rinse and repeat. If I was still having problems I was supposed to be immediately scheduled for surgery. Then I started doing some research on cancer and found out that there are hundreds of thousands of people who are living today (this was 1997) precisely because they learned to heal themselves and to refuse to listen to the invasive surgical and toxic synthetic drug advice that so called Doctors like to peddle. Long story short. I learned how to heal myself naturally and never went back to see those scammin g doctors again until about a year later when I had them give me a seal of approval for being cancer free. That experience gave me a completely different perspective than the malarkey th at Doctors are professionals and that they are educated.

replies.commentText: Lmfao lemme guess, you cured your cancer with essential oils and prayer?

commentThread.commentText: The whole thing with his teeth is that he wanted the dentist to put the bonding on the ends of his teeth, not actually attached to anything which means there's a good chance those things are just going to snap off the end of his teeth in a year.

Older bodies do not rebound as fast as young bodies, hence why doctors are hesitant to do invasive procedures on older patients. If you want something done, I'm positive you will find a doctor willing to do it. I am an ortho/trauma/neuro and emergency nurse, we make decisions based on the best possible outcome but we respect patient and their families choices, hence , the 99 year old full code who's family wants every single fucking thing done to their two steps from death mother. Also why we allow family in the room during CPR, let them see what we're doing to keep their skeleton of a family member alive

I could not disagree more, if anything in my experience doctors are ageist, but it's against younger people. At least in the UK I find if you go to a doctor with some kind of ailment and you're under 50 they absolutely do not want to know you and brush you off with a "you're young so you probably don't have anything and even if you do you'll more than likely recover on your own, you know, since you're young"

replies.commentText: whether someone has an issue at all is a different question, they just mean specifically treatments they give for conditions. But also I agree, I accidentally cut my fifth finger and cut a tendon, couldn't move it all, and it took the ER 6 hours of convincing that I wasn't just in pain, I physically could not move the finger. They were busy that day, but still. I overheard the nurse on the phone before I went in, and had to correct her when she spoke under her breath saying she didn't think I tore anything.

Listen u dumb fucks. I'm a fake doctor (dentist), and our fucking hands are tied when it comes to treatment. Insurance companies run the game. I dont even think about ideal treatment sometimes because patients routinely and consistently decline it due to a fucking 'fixed income'. Guess what ass-wads? EVERYONE IS ON A FIXED INCOME. Also, going to a 4 year, plus dental school, plus buying into a dental practice (or starting your own) gets me easily to over 1 mil in debt. WTF? Also, guess what loan you cant declare bankruptcy on!!!?? Fucking school loans. As I literally am now working two jobs, since being a fucking doctor wasnt paying the loans and bills, I really despise any person that is milking the system. Apparently working hard and attempting to achieve the best fiscally responsible profession for my family's well-being, is no longer enough and I was fucking lied to by the boomers out there. The times have changed, and being on youtube is now your best bet.

When I was in the army retired Master Sargent age 78 Froze his retirement wanted to get Command Sargent Major before actually retire completely. He joined my unit and during our PT test. We both did 148 push-ups, beat me in sit-ups 103 to my 92 (I take it easy on my situps because of back issues.) One of the fastest runners in my unit. Our runs times 10:03 was my time. I could have easily got it below 9 if I pushed it a little harder. But the Master Sargent's time was 7:38 on the 2-mile run. So I know for a fact. Being old doesn't mean a damn thing physically. He and got along because I was the only one who knew who "The Duke" was. lol which was funny and sad at the same time. I was 27 year s old at the time but I was rais ed old school.

commentThread.commentText: That's not ageist... That's risk benefit that drs have to deal with because if not they get sued...

replies.commentText: So true, not to mention that most people are non-compliant with treatment plans.
Yeah I'm a nurse and everything he said I'm sitting here like '...dude that's not ageist it's common sense'
@imlee888 id like to hear you elaborate on that point?

Remy old people (in general, not necessarily his age, and regarding dentistry I'm not very familiar with, but take this first point in a general sense) take longer to recover from certain things. For instance 99% of orth o doctors won't do a bilateral knee replacement on anyone over 80, because the recovery takes so long and the quality of living will be reduced and it wouldn't be worth it. In terms of his example with statins, generally we try to get patients to change lifestyle choices to eliminate the origin of the problem, instead of just treating the symptoms.

Wrong. Researcher here. While risk is a valid concern, this is nothing more than an excuse that mistakes statistical trends as impinging upon individual situations rather than understanding rote outcome data alone is nothing more than rote outcome data and doesn't imply anything about what direction individual instances will take with further defaulting to baser human laziness that sheds light on the fact tha t doctors and nurses are far too commonly little more med techs with fancier titles and not scientists willing and able to seek solutions by looking into why a procedure did or didn't take - explains the chapels in hospitals. And most "professionals" are complicit in this, as the murse demonstrated, often hiding behin d "common sense" or worse "best methods" rhetoric unwilling to acknowledge such ideas are rooted in an unwillingness to admit not knowing which option is best, let alone right, due to not having needed data to indicate which actually is best due to, at worst, an unwillingness to obtain that data, so defaulting to the methods that has the highest outcome scores is most sensible when in reality it's not much more than good enough a reason to try that option first.

@imlee888 ....i don't get why people are saying 80 years old? Joe was saying they wouldn't fix his MCL and he's 51. And had a friend in his 50's that the wouldn't replace fix his ACL. I don't think they were complaining about someone who's 80 getting knee replacement. I guess just so you can say they're wrong? You move the goal-post then correct them so you feel smart?
